title: Spamming any user from Reset Password Function

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
It is possible to spam any user whose email-id is known. This can be combined with csrf attack i.e automated to send 50 emails with a click. This is reset password form --->

Forgot password

To retrieve your password enter the email address you used to sign up.

Here, authencity token can be used more than one. Users can be spammed heavily by just simple coding a script. Only email-id should be known. I tried it on my own account. I was able to use the token for more than 5 attempts. This is not best practice. Only one try must be allowed.

activities.message:
Hi @pranav_hivarekar, thanks for your submission. Besides this behaviour being potentially annoying, it doesn't have any security implications. These kind of best practices are somewhere on our roadmap, but we don't consider them urgent. We have several monitoring tools in place that notify us when people actively abuse such functionality. Closing the issue as not applicable because I don't see any harm in the concern you raised here. Also keep in mind that you can also do this by simply sending a thousand emails to a certain email address.

Side note: noticed you submitted a series of best practices to us lately.. This is fine by me, but please note that we're most interested in bugs that actually have (in)direct security implications (such as XSS, CSRF, RCE, SQLI or authentication/authorization bypasses - to name a few). I'm sure you know a lot about security, but try to focus more on bugs that are exploitable (also for the cash bonuses we reward for real security bugs - we love to pay for awesome finds!). Thanks again and happy bug hunting!
